title: Millstone Edge Walk Route

images.title: Robin Drayton / The viewpoint at Surprise View
images.caption: The viewpoint at Surprise View. Looking towards Hathersage and the Hope Valley.

images.title: Martin Speck / Millstone Edge
images.caption: Millstone Edge seen from the A6187 (formerly the A625) near Whim Plantation.

images.title: Millstone Edge by Jonathan Clitheroe, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Millstone Edge

images.title: A grindstone and Mother Cap by Martin Speck, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A grindstone and Mother Cap. Millstone Edge quarry was one of the main sources of Peak District millstones which were made to be used in many industries such as grinding corn, pulping timber for paper manufacture, in paint mills to grind minerals, grindstones for cutlery, pulping apples for cider making, grinding cork for linoleum and grinding mustard seeds.

images.title: At Over Owler Tor by Neil Theasby, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: At Over Owler Tor

images.title: Millstone in the heather, below Millstone Edge by Andrew Hill, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Millstone in the heather, below Millstone Edge. A millstone shaped from Millstone Grit quarried in the area has been adopted as the emblem of the Peak District National Park. Quarrying ended at Millstone Edge soon after the last stones were sold to a Swedish paper mill in 1939. Unsold flat millstones stones from this period can still be seen by the footpath.

images.title: Silver birch and gritstone by Peter Barr, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Silver birch and gritstone

description: This circular walk climbs to Millstone Edge near Hathersage in the Peak District. The area is great for interesting geology and fabulous views over the surrounding peaks and countryside. You can start the walk from the Surprise view car park off the A1687. From here you can pick up trails heading west to the Surprise view viewpoint. The route then continues north along Millstone Edge. Here you can enjoy lots of pretty heather in the summer and fine views over Hathersage and the Hope Valley. The area also includes Master's Edge, a rock climbing route considered one of the hardest gritstone climbing routes in the world. The route then bends round to Over Owler Tor and Mother Cap where there are more splendid rock formations and huge millstones to see. To extend the walk head south from the car park to climb to Owler Tor. You can also explore the wonderful Padley Gorge Trail and the Longshaw Estate here.
